Byrne J, Wild T, Maximova K, Browne N, Holt N, Cave A, Martz P, Ellendt C, Ball G. A brief eHealth tool delivered in primary care to help parents prevent childhood obesity: a randomized controlled trial. Pediatr Obes; in press.

Author.author:Name: Martz, Patricia
Author.author:Affiliation: Ministry of Health, Government of Alberta

citation:Description.dsDescription:Text: The objective of this study was to determine the feasibility and preliminary impact of an eHealth screening, brief intervention and referral to treatment (SBIRT) tool delivered in primary care to help parents prevent childhood obesity. The SBIRT was entitled RIPPLE - the Resource Information Program for Parents on Lifestyle and Education. Parents of children were recruited from a primary care clinic and invited to participate in the SBIRT on a study-designated tablet. The SBIRT was brief (~15 minutes) and parents completed it while they awaited their child's upcoming pediatrician appointment. The SBIRT (i) screened for children's weight status using children's measured height and weight, (ii) randomly assigned parents to one-of-four brief interventions (two on nutrition, two on physical activity) or an eHealth control group, and (iii) provided parents with a menu of resources (i.e., online handouts, information on community services) to help prevent obesity in children.

Grant Information.grantNumber:Grant Agency: Alberta Innovates - Health Solutions (AIHS); Canadian Institutes of Health Research (CIHR);Public Health Agency of Canada (PHAC)

ore:describes.citation:Related Material: Avis JLS, Holt NL, Maximova K, van Mierlo T, Fournier R, Padwal R, Cave AL, Martz P, Ball GDC. The Development and Refinement of an e-Health Screening, Brief Intervention, and Referral to Treatment for Parents to Prevent Childhood Obesity in Primary Care. Telemedicine and e-Health. April 2016, 22(5): 385-394. doi:10.1089/tmj.2015.0128.
ore:describes.socialscience:Collection Mode: Self-administered questionnaire: E-mail; Self-administered questionnaire: Web-based; Physical measurements and tests;  Psychological measurements and tests
ore:describes.Data Sources: Modified version of survey was based on the following study: Campbell M, Benton JM, Werk L. Parent Perceptions to Promote a Healthier Lifestyle for Their Obese Child. Social Work in Health Care. 2011; 50:10, 787-800.  doi:10.1080/00981389.2011.597316
ore:describes.Alternative Title: A Brief eHealth Tools Delivered in Primary Care to Help Parents Prevent Childhood Obesity: A Randomized Controlled Trial
ore:describes.Title: The Resource Information Program for Parents on Lifestyle and Education (RIPPLE): A Parent-based eHealth Tool to Prevent Childhood Obesity
ore:describes.socialscience:Universe: Parents and their 5 - 17 year old children receiving health care at the Allin Clinic (Edmonton Oliver Primary Care Network).
ore:describes.socialscience:Frequency: Data was collected at baseline and at one month follow-up.
ore:describes.Subject: Medicine, Health and Life Sciences
ore:describes.socialscience:Actions to Minimize Losses: Cards reminding parents about the follow-up visit were given out.
ore:describes.socialscience:Characteristics of Data Co: A brief, eight-item Likert scale questionnaire with established face validity was adopted from Campbell et al. (2011) and assessed parents' concern about their child's weight status and intention to change or improve their child's lifestyle behaviors. Specifically, parents assigned to the brief nutrition-based intervention received questions that queried concern about their child's weight and intention to change their child's dietary habits, and parents assigned to the brief physical activity-based intervention received questions that queried concern about their child's weight and intention to change their child's physical activity habits; parents assigned to the control group (Heads Up!) received both sets of questions. As a token of appreciation and to encourage parents to complete the 1-month follow-up measure, parents were given a Can $25 gift card to a local business (eg, grocery store).
ore:describes.Kind of Data: Questionnaire data; Clinical data; Anthropometric data
ore:describes.socialscience:Sampling Procedure: The target number of study participants was 200; the actual number of study participants was 226. Participants were randomly assigned to one-of-four brief intervention arms (n=179) or the eHealth control group (n=47).
ore:describes.schema:name: The Resource Information Program for Parents on Lifestyle and Education (RIPPLE): A Parent-based eHealth Tool to Prevent Childhood Obesity
ore:describes.dvcore:conditions:
Access to deidentified data may be permitted for external researchers, w
ith limitations. Only researchers with REB-approved projects may be permitted access to the deidentified data. The data producer determines access on a case-by-case basis. Contact the data producer directly to discuss terms and conditions of access.

dvcore:fileTermsOfAccess.dvcore:dataAccessPlace: Data captured by the RIPPLE program is stored on a secure server maintained by Evolution Health Systems, Inc., which is  located in Ontario. Electronic data related to this study will be destroyed after five years and all hard copies will be shredded.
